channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #138 - TPF Grant proposals
item.description:
Hi,

sorry for the delayed posting, I had an unplanned 2-days vacation with my daughter. It was great, and I am sorry to say, that preparing the Perl Weekly came in only a second in my priorities.

I hope you also enjoyed your weekend, and you are ready for a new set of articles:
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Call for Venue for YAPC::Europe::2015
item.description: Would you like to have a Perl conference in your (European) city? This is your chance to put your city on the world map! The dead-line for sending letter of intent is Friday, 25 April, and then you'll still have 2 months to actually prepare your proposal or hide under a stone.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2014 - Just 20 tickets left - T-14 days
item.description: That was on March 11. I am not sure if they still have any more tickets left.

item.title: Evolvable languages
item.description: Jeffrey Kegler shows some Perl code that is obviously incorrect, to the eyes of a long time Perl developer, but that seems natural. He then shows how, with the help of a Marpa preprocessor this syntax could be allowed.

item.title: Perl Encryption Primer: The Importance of Randomness
item.description: Timm Murray from the Wumpus Cave explains how rand() works and why it is not a good tool when security is important. He then goes on to suggest adding extra hardware if randomness is really important, or at least to use Crypt::Random.

item.title: How did PHP and Python take over such a huge market-share of Perl?
item.description: In a nutshell: the 'ease of getting started' and 'batteries included' are two keys in those stories and while there are other issues, without solving these two Perl has no chance in getting in the ring again.

item.title: A Faster Perl Runtime in Tiny Steps
item.description: Apparently now Booking.com is sponsoring Dave Mitchell directly to improve the performance of perl. Steffen Muller explains the changes Dave made in a human readable way.

item.title: Precision Testing for Modern Perl
item.description: Toby Inkster argues that Test::Most is old, has some outdated dependencies and cannot be changed because modules depend on it. Hence he released Test::Modern with a set of dependencies that are good now. I applaud the recommendations, but I think this is not a good path. IMHO it would be better to find a way to update Test::Most.

item.title: Test::More - New Maintainer, Also stop version checking!
item.description: Chad 'Exodist' Granum is the new maintainer of Test::More. If you have been experimenting with the 1.5 branch, you might need to update your code!

item.title: How soon do CPAN Testers start testing your releases?
item.description: It is only based on data from a single CPAN distribution, but so far it shows that the bulk of the test reports arrive in the first 8 days after the release reaches PAUSE with some reports arriving within the first hour!

item.title: Perl RegEx /s /m Magic
item.description: Sebastian Willing explains the 3 modifiers: /s, /m, and .

item.title: pjam on rails - build server for perl applications
item.description: This looks like some strange animal. A build-server for Perl applications, but running on Ruby on Rails? You might want to check it out and let everyone know what's it about?

item.title: What happens when you upload to CPAN?
item.description: This is the first part of a series in which Neil Bowers tries to explain to himself and to you how the whole CPAN ecosystem works. Do you know what is PAUSE and what BackPAN?

item.title: You Can Help MetaCPAN by Helping the QA Hackathon
item.description: In general MetaCPAN does not accept monetary contributions, but being able to participate at the annual QA Hackathon helps Olaf Alders to allocate time to work on MetaCPAN and get others to be involved. So if you'd like to help MetaCPAN with money, the best way is to donate to the QA Hackathon. (See reports about this years QA Hackathon in the Testing section above.)

item.title: Sometimes, all it takes is a simple change to make your Perl code run on Windows
item.description: The difference between directory separator characters between Windows and Linux has tripped me many times. Especially in test. Now Sinan Unur shows how we could improve our tests script be be less platform dependent.

item.title: perldoc -l for modules without pod
item.description: Did you know that 'perldoc -lm Module::Name will print the path to a module even if it does not have POD? You can open it in vim by typing 'vim $(perldoc -lm Module::Name)'

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 7
item.description: The report by Tony Cook.

item.title: March 2014 Grant Proposals
item.description: After many months without any grant requests, and after raising the grant limit from 3,000 to 10,000, the last call for grant proposals brought you 4 grant proposals. The Perl Foundation is looking forward to read your comments and thoughts.

item.title: Changes for week 10 of 2014 Mar 10
item.description: This is the Perl 6 weekly

item.title: What goes around, comes around
item.description: Vikings being attacked by an Aussie! More specifically, Damian Conway is visiting Oslo and teaching his Perl Masterclass on Monday, 24 March.

item.title: Installing a Perl Module from CPAN on Windows, Linux and Mac OSX
Perl-related events
item.description: In the following cities: Hannover (DE), Cluj (RO), Swindon (UK), Utrecht (NL), Silver Spring, (MD/USA), Poznan (PL), Prague (CZ), Oslo (NO), Paris (FR), Kiev (UA), Orlando (FL/USA), Sofia (BG), FlÃ¶rli Olten (CH)
